destination.label: Cancun
destination.title: Cancun: the gateway to the Yucatán

content.intro:
This modern, vibrant city is the ideal starting point to visiting the area.

Cancun is on the northeast coast of the Yucatan Peninsula in the state of Quintana Roo, bordered by the Caribbean Sea and the Nichupte Lagoon. This large seaside resort is famous for its beaches, crystal-clear waters, and sultry nights. Cancun has huge hotels, five golf courses, shopping centres, evening entertainment, amusement parks, nightclubs, and sports activities. If you are in search of quiet and authenticity, head for the Yucatan. In this region, the cradle of Mayan civilisation, you will learn about the country's history as well as discover heavenly beaches. Visit the Chichen Itza archaeological site and Coba pyramid, one of the few open to the public for climbing. Take a boat trip to Isla Mujeres to enjoy its Caribbean island atmosphere and traditional restaurants. If you have time, explore hidden Isla Holbox, where you can swim with hammerhead sharks and watch flamingos. Spend a few days in Tulum, where you can stay in boho-chic hotels, dine in trendy restaurants, and visit sublime ruins overlooking the Caribbean Sea. Take the time to dive into cenotes (gorgeous natural sinkholes, filled with azure waters), watch turtles lay their eggs at Akumal or get lost in the jungle of Palenque. If you dream of discovering Mexico from the Spanish era, go to Merida. In this very pretty colonial town, you'll love getting lost among its arenas, old buildings, and haciendas. Along your journey, taste fresh fish tacos, grilled fish over a wood fire with spicy sauces, shrimp nachos, and other traditional recipes. The Mayan Pyramids, sublime jungle, white sand beaches, and turquoise water is what makes the Yucatan the number one tourist destination in all of Latin America.

content.title: Marakame blows a wind of relaxation

introduction.small: Among the many palm trees, the restaurant offers quality international cuisine during the day and stimulating cocktails by night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marakame blows a wind of relaxation

paragraphs.text:
The setting is truly enchanting: at the heart of an island of greenery, you will pick an outdoor table on the large wooden terrace or in the first-floor dining room. Close to both the city centre and the Cancun seafront, Marakame offers two types of experiences: during the day, whether for breakfast, brunch or lunch, you will taste local flavours, or take a journey to the United States, Italy or even France. The restaurant takes pride in serving among the freshest fish and seafood of the whole region. Alternately, you may just stop by for midday coffee and enjoy a relaxing break.

When night falls, lanterns are turned on and musicians climb up on stage. Mixologists take over and skilfully serve martinis, mimosas and mango margaritas, sangria, beer and local wine – all to be enjoyed in moderation, of course. A genuine change of scenery!

content.title: Tacun, simplicity and authenticity on a budget

introduction.small: Amid the large Cancun hotel zone, Tacun stands out with very affordable pricing, traditional cooking and a kitsch atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tacun, simplicity and authenticity on a budget

paragraphs.text:
Simple is sometimes best. In Cancun, Tacun lives up to the notion. This outdoor restaurant located in the Cancun hotel zone makes no fuss. On the terrace, locals and tourists enjoy authentic Mexican cuisine, from breakfast onward. Traditional tacos, burritos and quesadillas, but also seafood – whole lobster and shrimp – are served in kitsch-looking dinner sets, seemingly taken from a local grandma's buffet. Tacun plays off that rococo side and adds wax cloths, multicoloured chairs, piñatas and bandanas, the latter two hanging from the ceiling. The decoration really stands out in the neighbourhood, but less so than the restaurant's pricing, which even holds all around Cancun! Make sure you carry enough cash though, as the establishment does not take cards.

content.title: Romantic atmosphere at La Fonda del Zancudo

introduction.small: Far from the guided tours in Cancún's city centre, La Fonda del Zancudo restaurant will lure you in with charming fusion gastronomy with European influences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Romantic atmosphere at La Fonda del Zancudo

paragraphs.text:
Behind the wrought iron gate top with a sign, a few old wooden tables have been arranged in the courtyard of this long-standing yet restored house in Cancún. Bougainvillaea trees and other climbing plants cover the whole structure of the building. This rustic look is magnified by the use of oil lamps suspended by a cord, while the clear moonlight brightens the dishes a little further.
A large wood-framed blackboard hung on roughcast render displays the dailies, as well as available quantity of each dish. A few ingredients are farmed in the restaurant's own vegetable garden, as La Fonda del Zancudo highlights raw, fresh, local and often organic products. You may be able to try the famous figs stuffed with goat cheese and prosciutto, the Angus beef medallions with butter and sage sauce, served with grilled corn, or the cone of fresh salmon with avocado, mango and fresh cheese. An intimate atmosphere for a perfectly romantic dinner in Cancún.

content.title: Gourmet break at Café con Gracia

introduction.small: Only a stone's throw from Mercado 28 in Cancún, Café con Gracia welcomes strollers looking for a sweet break in a vintage and cosy environment.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gourmet break at Café con Gracia

paragraphs.text:
Turquoise colour is everywhere to be found on the terrace, as it catches the eye and stirs up curiosity. The walls, aged wooden chairs and elements of decoration such as a 1970s bike have all been painted in this colour at Café con Gracia. In this vintage establishment, furniture has been bargain-hunted, recycled and restored. Inside, a typewriter stands in an alcove, and books are scattered here and there. The shop makes it very clear, books and reading go hand in hand with coffee and pastries. Locals often gather to enjoy an iced drink, as they're famous all around town and offered in various flavours, from mango to mint through candy floss and the in-demand lemon pie. Sip it on the terrace, or in the garden at the back of the shop.

content.title: The sunken sculptures of the Museo Subacuático de Arte

introduction.small: The waters surrounding Cancùn, Isla Mujeres and Punta Nizuc, harbour a thousand treasures. Dive down to see the sculptures that populate the seabed like a real sunken city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The sunken sculptures of the Museo Subacuático de Arte

paragraphs.text:
More than 500 human-scale sculptures inhabit the clear waters of Cancún. This underwater museum was designed in 2009 by Roberto Díaz Abraham and Jaime González Cano to demonstrate the relationship between art and the environment. The first to sculpt for this project was the Englishman Jason DeCaires Taylor, followed by other artists such as Karen Salinas Martinez, Roberto Diaz Abraham and Salvador Quiroz Ennis.

These sculptures serve as an artificial reef and blend completely into their environment so that you will think that you have discovered Atlantis as you approach. It is today the largest underwater museum in the world.

Three options are available to admire the works. If you prefer to stay dry, you can choose a glass-bottom boat. If you are not afraid to get wet, you can opt for snorkelling. And, if you want to see the statues up close, diving tours are

content.title: Have fun at Xcaret Eco Park

introduction.small: An adventure outing in a popular park with a natural underground river.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Have fun at Xcaret Eco Park

paragraphs.text:
Located in Riviera Maya, about 60 kilometres south of Cancun International Airport and six kilometres from Playa del Carmen, Xcaret offers entertainment for all. It is an amusement park, nature reserve, and archaeological site all rolled into one, and it is impossible to do everything in one day. Guests can swim with dolphins, purify body and mind through the Mayan sweat-lodge ritual of temazcal, feed sharks in the Caribbean Sea, discover 20 different butterfly species, some of which are endangered, and even visit vestiges of Mayan civilisation. These buildings were once part of a port and a ceremonial centre where Mayans used to come together and bathe to purify themselves. The most famous attraction in the park is the underground river. Swim in an almost 800-metre-long river of crystal-clear water through caves encrusted with marine fossils and stalactite formations. Stay after sundown to enjoy the incredible night show, with its traditional Mexican dances. If you are near here during the Halloween period, come for the Day of the Dead festivities.

introduction.small: A trendy, stylish hotel in the heart of Playa del Carmen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Be Playa, a charming hotel

paragraphs.text:
Sixty kilometres south of Cancun, Be Playa is a charming hotel on the festive Playa del Carmen. The 23 rooms in this four-star hotel have blue and red hammocks, elegant and luxurious open-plan spaces, and circular bathtubs. Junior suites have hot tubs and balconies.

Metal birdcages and vintage chalkboards are nice details in a classic design that mixes white and honey-coloured wood, polished concrete, polished floors, and immaculate linens. Its restaurant serves the best sushi in the city, but the real secret of Be Playa is a rooftop swimming pool. This is where jet-set partygoers go for the best cocktails and fantastic views of the ocean. Enjoy a typical Mezcal cocktail while you admire the most beautiful sunsets over the city.

introduction.small: The Yucatan cenotes are a unique underground water network.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cenote swimming

paragraphs.text:
Among the most amazing natural phenomena of the Yucatan Peninsula, cenotes are tunnel-shaped cavities. Dug into the limestone by groundwater, they became exposed to the surface with the collapse of their limestone ceilings.

Formerly Mayan ritual sites, cenotes are now family recreation areas for Mexicans and tourists. The peninsula has no less than 10,000 cenotes, of which only a few are known and have been explored.

Enjoy these stunning pools for snorkelling, diving, and swimming in the middle of the region's wild nature. In Riviera Maya, we recommend the Cristalino cenote, 70 metres from the southern entrance of the Barceló Maya resort, as well as Cenote Azul and El Jardin del Edén, which are also accessible along the highway, a little further south.

introduction.small: A trip into a jungle paradise.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maroma Resort & Spa

paragraphs.text:
Built in a beautiful, unspoilt tropical jungle area of Riviera Maya, Maroma Resort and Spa is a luxurious resort with whitewashed walls, a thatched roof, tropical palms, white sand beaches, and an imposing mahogany staircase in the lobby. Expect to be greeted with a margarita. With white interiors and rustic wood, Maroma's 65 rooms are decorated with hand-painted tiles, local furniture, original art, bamboo blinds, sunken baths decorated with Mexican terracotta tiles, and balconies with hammocks woven especially for the hotel. Start the day with a yoga class before you bask in one of three outdoor pools, sit in the Jacuzzi, or relax on a luxurious deckchair installed on the beach. Maroma's trendy tapas restaurant, El Sol, features a Mediterranean menu with a Mexican touch. Freddy's is the perfect place for an evening stroll under the stars. Do not miss an afternoon relaxing in the breath-taking Kinan Spa, with its waterfalls, private pools, and unique Mayan treatments.

introduction.small: Twenty kilometres from Tulum, Akumal is a divine hideaway on the Yucatan Peninsula.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore Akumal, turtle country

paragraphs.text:
Meaning ‘place of the turtles' in ancient Mayan, the small town of Akumal is transformed every May when turtles come in from the coast to spawn.

Throughout the year, Akumal is a diving town, where people come to explore the seabed and its incredible caves and canyon that form a veritable underwater mountain landscape. Its coral reefs are home to a wide variety of marine species that swim fearlessly with divers. You can rent a sea kayak or go snorkelling amongst stingrays, turtles, and many species of colourful fish.

The nearby Aktun-Chen Natural Park is renowned for its lush landscapes and rich wildlife. You will come across monkeys, spiders, and snakes in their natural environment. During your visit, be sure to go for a dip in the cool waters of its sublime cenote (a natural water-filled pit).

Akumal
Quintana Roo

introduction.small: An eco-chic restaurant in the jungle of Tulum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hartwood, ecological

paragraphs.text:
Under Tulum's palm trees behind the beach, Hartwood is one of the best-known addresses in the city. It is an open-air restaurant with rustic wooden tables and antique furniture, which the owners collected during their travels. In the evenings, it is lit by glowing lanterns. Highly environment friendly, Hartwood runs only on solar power and serves only local products. Its artisanal recipes, wood stoves, and open barbecues make Hartwood an especially tasty experience.

Former New Yorkers Eric Werner and Mya Henry opened this tropical restaurant with a philosophy of simplicity and a daily menu of fresh fish and dishes cooked in hot pots. Enjoy a rustic spicy grapefruit margarita and savour a sirloin beefsteak with pimentos and lime, or grilled octopus and crispy potatoes.

If you want to experiment, make a same-day booking by adding your name to the 3:00 p.m. slot.

Opened in 2013, Nizuc Resort & Spa has been called the best hotel in Mexico many times. Originally designed to house a private presidential retreat and a national park, this very modern hotel with clean lines sits in the middle of a 29-hectare nature reserve in one of the most remote enclaves in Riviera Maya.

In the midst of all this unspoilt nature is a top-flight hotel, designed by the Mexican architect, Alejandro Escudero. It offers infinity pools, beaches, and Mexican jungle. In this exclusive and wonderfully Zen paradise, you will find 274 rooms and suites, including 29 Garden Pool Villas, six world-renowned restaurants, three trendy cocktail bars, five magnificent pools, an ESPA spa, and two tennis courts.

introduction.small: Get away for the day to enjoy paradise far from the bustle of Cancun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Escape to Isla Mujeres

paragraphs.text:
Isla Mujeres is eight kilometres long, 500 metres wide, and located just six kilometres from the northeast coast of Cancun. 'Isla' its nickname and its exceptional coastline make a refreshing break from the craziness of Cancun. Its clear waters, marine life, reefs, and caves attracted Jacques Cousteau, who was brought there by Mexican diver Ramón Bravo.

Far from resorts and shopping centres, the majority of Islanders make their living diving and fishing. Get around by renting mopeds, golf carts, and bicycles, or by taking taxis. The northern tip of the island, where the ferries come in, is the most inhabited part. This is where the shops, restaurants, bars, and brightly coloured houses are. In the southern part of the city, a road leads to a mangrove lagoon where there are great beaches and restaurants next to the water. It takes about 20 minutes in some form of transport to get to the south end of the island.

The east coast is rocky and wild, and there are few amenities. If you crave adventure, visit El Garrafon Marine Park where you can go underwater hiking, zip-lining, kayaking, diving, and swimming maybe even with dolphins.

www.isla-mujeres.net

content.title: Lose yourself in the Palenque rainforest

introduction.small: At the heart of the jungle, the Mayan ruins of Palenque take you back to another era.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lose yourself in the Palenque rainforest

paragraphs.text:
Nestled amidst a dense tropical forest, near the Usumacinta River, Palenque is one of the most beautiful Mayan cities of Mexico. Palenque, which means ‘surrounded by trees,' is one of those timeless places where one wanders through the jungle, past gorgeous waterfalls, while following one of the many trails, some of which take you to moss-covered temples lost in the fog.

Discovered in the late 18th century, the site is still being explored and reconstructed. The ruins have not yet revealed all their treasure, as only 10% of the site has been uncovered. This mysterious, enchanted site is one of the best examples of the stone and stucco achievements of Mayan pyramid architecture and statuary. Among the many buildings, the most interesting is the Temple of the Inscriptions, a stunning nine-storey pyramid that contains the sarcophagus of King Pakal.

content.title: The island of Cozumel: heaven on earth

introduction.small: Its Caribbean charm attracts thousands of visitors every year.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The island of Cozumel: heaven on earth

paragraphs.text:
Across from Playa del Carmen, Cozumel is a perfect getaway from the madness of the city. In one day, you will discover the traditions of this Caribbean island, its natural wonders, and its village, San Miguel.

A paradise for divers and snorkelers, Cozumel has beautiful turquoise waters and white sandy beaches, making it a required stopover for cruises passing by on the Caribbean. Treat yourself to a session of snorkelling at Stingray Beach to see stingrays, and to feed, pet, and even swim with them.

Take a tour in a flat-bottomed boat to El Cielo to observe the starfish. More experienced and adventurous divers will be attracted to ‘Devil's Throat', a spiral cave that goes down from 24 to 41 metres.

content.title: Climb to the top of the Coba Pyramid

introduction.small: The Mayan city of Coba is one of the main archaeological sites of the Yucatan.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climb to the top of the Coba Pyramid

paragraphs.text:
Unlike other major cities, such as its eternal rival Chichen Itza, Coba shone not only during the classical period between the seventh and 10th centuries, but again between the 13th and 16th centuries. In the middle of the jungle, 50 kilometres from Tulum, wild, unspoilt Coba is beautiful.

It has three different groups of buildings located away from each other. Discover them on foot, rented bike, or in a Mayan rickshaw.

Climb the tallest pyramid in the Mexican Mayan world at your own risk, and be rewarded with an impressive panoramic view of the surrounding jungle. At a height of 40 metres, Nohoch Mul, meaning ‘big mound' in Mayan, is the largest pyramid in the Yucatan, and the last that visitors are still allowed to climb.

introduction.small: Relax on Holbox, a remote island with white sandy beaches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Escape to tropical Isla Holbox

paragraphs.text:
Off the northern coast of the Yucatan peninsula, a two-hour drive from Cancun, Isla Holbox is separated from the mainland by a shallow lagoon full of pelicans, dolphins, and flamingos. Here, cars are not allowed hence, the island is best explored on foot, bicycle, or by golf cart.

You will find rental companies at every street corner. Dive with whale sharks and hammerheads, kayak in the mangroves in search of alligators, and ride a horse on the white sand beaches. Take a yoga session at dawn at one of Holbox's hippie chic beach hotels.

A sandbank just off the island in the middle of the water is a wonderful place to go for a walk. Stay at Dream, a traditional hotel on a beautiful beach. Guests enjoy an ultra-fresh breakfast, terraces with hammocks, and two refreshing pools, perfect after a day exploring the island.

content.title: Los Aguachiles, master of the ceviche

introduction.small: Mingle with locals in this restaurant, renowned for its ceviche and tacos.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Los Aguachiles, master of the ceviche

paragraphs.text:
Off the beaten path, Los Aguachiles is one of Playa del Carmen's best kept secrets. This real neighbourhood restaurant serves hearty Mexican dishes, especially ceviche (marinated raw fish, lemon juice, and red onions), which is what the restaurant is famous for, as well as tacos and ultra-fresh seafood. Fill your corn tortillas with shrimp or tuna, coriander sauce, spicy Mexican sauce, creamed spinach, refried beans, spicy mushrooms, and, above all, the best guacamole in Playa del Carmen.

Its clientele of locals, tourists, and New Yorkers makes the atmosphere relaxed. Take a seat at one of the plastic tables looking out on 34th Street, enjoy complimentary homemade tortillas, and watch the world go by while you wait for your meal.

South of Cancun, in the heart of a five-hectare tropical paradise and facing the white sandy beach of Petempich Bay, Hotel Zoëtry Paraiso de la Bonita Riviera Maya has stylish rooms with stunning views, healthy gourmet cuisine, and soothing spa treatments that nourish the body and awaken the senses.
Zoëtry offers a unique experience in which one's wellbeing is king.

The hotel features North America's first certified thalassotherapy centre, equipped with a seawater pool and 16 treatment rooms, a world-renowned restaurant, and a private catamaran, called the Canoa. There are also sublime mangroves to explore, a private beach that stretches out over a kilometre, and a bird sanctuary. Everything is centred on relaxation and tranquillity.

The hotel also offers exclusive cultural, artistic, and educational experiences as well as local stewardship activities in the community.

introduction.small: The most grandiose —and most visited— ruins in Mexico.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Visit Chichen Itza's archaeological dig

paragraphs.text:
On top of what was once one of the largest Mayan cities, the ruins of Chichen Itza is one of the most visited archaeological sites in the country. They have also been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site and named one of the ‘Seven New Wonders of the World'.

Spread over 6.5 square kilometres, the site can be visited in a day. It has two distinct architectural zones: the southern zone, which has early Puuc-style buildings typical of the Yucatan region that date from the seventh century; and the central area, built after the arrival of the Toltecs around the 10th century, and characterised by the fusion of the Puuc architectural style with that of the central highlands of Mexico. Do not miss El Castillo, an imposing pyramid that has dominated the site since it was built in the first century. And do visit the huge Mayan playing field where men once played Pok-ta-Pok, an ancestral form of basketball.

If you decide to spend the night nearby, book a room at the Hacienda Chichen, a 16th century property that has been beautifully restored as a luxury hotel and spa.

https://www.chichenitza.com

introduction.small: Dine at the water's edge, with your bare feet in the sand.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Completely relaxed at Zamas

paragraphs.text:
Zamas is a casual restaurant where you can have lunch or dinner barefoot in the sand under a thatched palapa right on the beach. Renowned for its seafood cuisine, the restaurant is distinguished by the freshness of its ingredients. Sit in one of the dining room's blue, bright red, and duck yellow wood chairs, and start off with complimentary chips and salsa. Before your eyes, chef Bryan Keller slides a freshly made pizza into the wood oven and prepares grilled seafood. The menu features spicy Caribbean tequila grilled grouper, snapper, or other local fish, grilled shrimp and lobster, and enchiladas poblano. Snacks are also given special attention, with honey fried chicken, cucumber and basil guacamole and king prawns in garlic. Do not miss favourites like caramelised bananas with vanilla ice cream and rum sauce. On some nights, Zamas hosts flamenco concerts, which make for a beautiful evening under the stars.

content.title: Live like a freewheeling hipster in Tulum

introduction.small: This boho-chic city, beside turquoise waters and sublime ruins, attracts a trendy crowd.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Live like a freewheeling hipster in Tulum

paragraphs.text:
Formerly known as Zama (‘Dawn'), the first explorers renamed this city Tulum, which means ‘wall' in the Mayan language. Tulum is a majestic archaeological site right on the sea. It is also a bohemian chic seaside resort that attracts hipsters from all around the world. In Tulum, bump into people like Orlando Bloom, Gisele Bündchen, and the Roitfeld family.

Do your yoga overlooking the ocean, detox with the freshest juices, and sample fusion food that blends world cuisine with Mexican flavours. At Tulum, you get up with the sun and go to bed early. This city has a special atmosphere. Everything is beautiful, Zen, and on a human scale. The trendy restaurants bring together Mexican and European inspirations.

People come for the weekend, rent bikes, and take advantage of kilometres of beach. Book a ‘cabana' at the Coco Tulum boutique hotel. These are small huts with thatched roofs that sit on the white sand surrounded by palm trees. Facing the sea, you will wake up to the sound of the waves before going to drink the kale, cucumber, and mango juice waiting for you at the beach bar.

Coco Tulum
Carretera Tulum Boca Paila Km 8
Tulum Beach
Quintana Roo

+52 984 688 8592

https://cocotulum.com

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Cancun
content.introduction: Cancún enjoys a tropical climate year-round. The dry season runs from November to May while the rainy (hurricane) season stretches from June to October. Temperatures remain relatively stable, ranging from average lows of 20°C to 25°C (68°F–77°F) to average highs of 26°C to 33°C (79°F–91°F).

airports.title: Cancún International Airport
airports.description:
Cancún International Airport is located approximately 20 kilometres (12 miles) from the city centre.
    • Four terminals
      • Terminal 1
      • Terminal 2
      • Terminal 3
      • Terminal 4 (Air France)
        Getting from the airport to Cancún and back:
    • By car
      • Accessible via motorway 307, about 20 minutes to the city centre.
      • There are several parking lots opposite the terminals: about MXN 30 for 1 hour; less than MXN 200 for 24 hours.
      • Several car rental companies have counters in Terminal 3.
    • By shuttle
      • A free shuttle service operates every 10 minutes between terminals.
    • By bus
      • ADO operates airport buses to the city centre every 30 minutes, with a stop in front of each terminal. Travel time is about 30 minutes and the fare is MXN 64 each way.
    • By taxi
      • Taxi ranks are located outside the arrival halls in Terminals 2 and 3. Fares to Cancún start at MXN 650.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +52 998 848 7200
  • Website: http://www.cancun-airport.net

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Cancun
transportation.description: Buses are the recommended way of getting around Cancún, as they are convenient, reliable and inexpensive. To explore the area around the city, the best options are taxis or rental cars.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Cancún, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Cancún Visitors Bureau (Dirección General de Turismo Municipal Cancún)
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Telephone: +52 998 887 3379

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Cancún counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
Visitors arriving from countries where yellow fever is endemic must show proof of yellow fever vaccination, usually documented on an International Certificate of Vaccination or Prophylaxis (ICVP). Obtaining a booster vaccination against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio is recommended. For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no food safety risks in Cancún.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is not safe to drink. Favour bottled mineral water instead.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: ¡ Buenos días ! (morning) / ¡ Buenas tardes ! (afternoon)
What time is it ?: ¿ Que hora es ?

Sorry: Disculpe (to say sorry)
Excuse me: Con permiso (to get past) / ¡ Por favor ! (to get attention).
How much is (…)?: ¿ Cuál es el precio de (…) ? /¿ Cuánto es ?
Where can I find (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo encontrar (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo comprar (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Cancun
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Cancún each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 6 : Epiphany (Día de los Santos Reyes, celebrated nationwide)
events.description: For the feast of the three kings, Mexicans get together with their families to share the rosca de reyes, a sweetbread baked in the shape of an oval ring, with a plastic figure of the baby Jesus concealed inside.

events.title: February/March: Spring Break (local event)
events.description: After their exams, huge numbers of American students come to party in the major Mexican seaside resorts: Acapulco, Puerto Vallarta, Cancún

events.title: May 5 : Anniversary of the Battle of Puebla  (Cinco de Mayo, national holiday)
events.description: Celebrated as a holiday throughout Mexico, commemorating the victory of the Mexican militia over the forces of Napoleon III in 1862.

events.title: September 16 : Independence Day (Grito de Dolores, national holiday)
events.description: This celebration commemorates the call to sedition issued by Priest Manuel Hidalgo y Costilla, on this day in 1810. Each year on the night of September 15, the Mexican president delivers a speech from its balcony. When he waves the nation's tricoloured flag, thousands of spectators cry out in unison, “Viva Mexico!”

events.title: November 1 and 2 : Días de los Muertos (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: With festivities that combine Christian and native traditions, this two-day celebration is a very important event for Mexicans. They evoke and pay tribute to the memory of their dearly departed with a festive celebration through prayer, song, music and dance.

events.title: December 12: Our Lady of Guadalupe (national holiday)
events.description: Celebration of Mexico's patron saint. Festivities throughout Mexico City and around the country include shows, dancing, concerts etc.

events.title: December 12: Our Lady of Guadalupe (national holiday)
events.description: Celebration of Mexico's patron saint. Festivities throughout Mexico City and around the country include shows, dancing, concerts etc.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Mexico
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be visiting Mexico as a tourist for less than 180 days. However, your passport must be valid for the entire period of your stay and you must be in possession of an onward or return ticket.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Cancún and Mexico, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Mexico page of the U.S. State Department’s travel Website: view information for travellers to Mexico

End of daylight saving time: first Sunday in November
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
Like in the United States, leaving a tip, called a propina, is expected in Mexico. In bars and restaurants, it is customary to tip between 10 and 15%. However, before leaving a tip, check the bill to make sure that a gratuity or service charge is not already included.
